Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Comment: “There is actually no definite article. … In some areas em, which is otherwise the third person singular personal pronoun, is used as if it were an article...”

Feature: Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?
Are there prenominal articles?
Are there postnominal articles?
What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Comment: “The clearest example of a demonstrative is prenominal dispela, often reduced to displa or most commonly, disla. Postnominal ia is generally considered to be a focus or emphatic marker, but Smith (2002:155-156) observes that in his data, it most often has an anaphoric function. It can also be used to direct the hearer’s attention to a referent in the environment.” The confidence of Smith & Siegel in coding for a postnominal demonstrative is ‘intermediate’, which I have reflected here in a question mark coding.

Comment: The plural marker precedes a noun when used additively but follows a name when used associatively.

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?
Comment: The examples given do not give the impression that any of the affixes for action/state nominalisations are productive.

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?
Comment: It is not clear whether the -a suffix is synchronically productive.

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?
Comment: The examples given do not give the impression that any of the affixes for object nominalisations are productive.

Is the adnominal possessive construction different for alienable and inalienable nouns?
Comment: Note that alienable and inalienable possession can be differentiated syntactically. However, they use the same morphosyntactic construction for adnominal possession.

Comment: “An alternative form of the third-person pronoun em is the suffix -en. This is attached only to the preposition long or to the possessive bilong which become longen and bilongen, respectively.”
